If you are going to say "no" you should explain why you feel that way. "No" is not a valid argument. It's just rude and dismissive. Sure my recommendations may be unbalanced or overpowered but the core of my argument is that trim should have some utility so solo players feel the need to search for them too. The whole trim addition to me just seems like a low effort novelty in 1.20 that'll be old news in a month or two. If trim sets had utility people might feel compelled to gather them all and make a netherite set for each one, which not only increases QOL in the endgame but vastly expands the course of endgame progression; many sets of netherite armor versus one.

I disagree. However, the armor trims would be a lot better if you could apply a second armor trim. Maybe a few of the armor trims could have some purpose such as gold allowing you to trade with piglins.

No me agrada la idea de agregar habilidades por las plantillas, entiendo que no tienen gran utilidad más que para verse bien pero no creo que sea necesario agregarle más facilidad a las cosas, además de que que pasa si tengo por ejemplo el recorte de la selva, del end, la fortaleza y una bastion en la armadura, si se combinan las habilidades lo veo muy desequilibrado y si se restan no le encontraría razón para obtener la habilidad si solo sirve poco, si quiero la habilidad tendría que utilizar la armadura completa con ese recorte aunque no me guste la combinación? Esa idea no me agrada, también digamos que se puede combinar, se tendría que más bien buscar formas que no estorben por ejemplo el que hace que se asusten los mobs es útil pero si en mi armadura tengo el que los asusta y quiero matar mobs por no se va a poder rápido o fácil porque se alejarían, yo pienso que la mejor idea sería que más bien con cada mineral que utilices le des algo por ejemplo si le pones oro a la armadura los pliglins no se enojan, pero no tantos cambios.

That's exactly what I'm wanting: for trims to have some purpose (QOL, extra stats, new abilities, etc) beyond just something to look at. Because solo players don't have anyone to show off to so the allure of braving many chests in an ancient city and wearing the silent armor as a badge of honor is lost on the solo player. Trim is worthless to me as a solo player. There is no one around for me toward whom I can flaunt my peacock feathers.

hello! i disagree with this because :   the trims were made for customization only, mostly as a ide quest, and some of them are pretty rare. and the game would be more boring , cause its too easy.  Thank you for reading this!

I like this idea -- I feel like this would make trims so much more worth it, and actually gives a reason to look for them.

 Additionally, I think golden trims should count as golden armor when it comes to piglins.

no, i disagree

the entire point of armor trims is vanity and customization, if the trims all gave buffs it would just be about the buffs.

the other purpose of armor trims is to easily differentiate between players in multiplayer, which would also become redundant as everybody would choose the same trims, since no matter how hard you try to balance the buffs, there would always be one stronger than the rest

I agree with the warden's bend, especially when it is running while charging up a sonic boom, but I disagree with the rest.

Mojang's internal quality standards have simply gone up a lot in the past couple of years and if anything, they should really take a look back at all the old content and bring it up to meet their new standards. Not only would that keep the game from looking dated, especially with the new additions there to show how much better it could be, but an update like that could give the older mobs some much needed bits of personality to them. Take Minecraft Dungeons as an example of what that might look like.
Yes, at least they need to make it consistent. But I think the animation of the older mobs are better for the feeling of Minecraft.

1. I disagree.
2. The warden moves like that to make it look creepier (which is important to it's intended role in the game. It is suppposed to feel like it is unnatural & doesn't belong.)
3. Would you animate the sniffer's digging and the camel's sitting differently or just remove those features (the primary features of those mobs...). Those are (again) the essential mechanics of those creatures.
4. I do think some of the older mobs could be updated significantly, like adding some more passive animations.

In reply to the post above me:

That's not the point.  You can't use ignorance as a defense.

It's an incredibly common mistake, yes, but why perpetuate ignorance?  Mojang has a chance to educate an entire generation of people and make a lot of archaeologists very happy.

Sherd - Wikipedia
Same as imposter or impostor

It is not the same as imposter or imposter.  Shard and Sherd are two completely different words.  They are not a spelling variation.

Shard is used for referring to a fragment of glass or crystal.  Sherd is specifically used for fragmented pottery.

Sherd is the preferred terminology used by archaeologists and scientists that work in the field.

Ask Wikipedia, or Google, or Youtube, or Chat GPD, or your friendly neighborhood archaeologist.  They will all tell you that sherd is the proper nomenclature for fragmented pottery in regard to archaeology.

From Grammarist: A sherd is a broken piece of pottery with edges that are sharp, usually referring to one that is found in an archaeological site. In essence, the words shard and sherd are interchangeable, though the term sherd is favored by archaeologists. Sherd is an abbreviation of the word potsherd, which has been in use since the 1300s. The plural of sherd is sherds.

I know this to be true because I myself worked in the Archaeology Department at my University as an undergrad and have since worked in several museums from all over the world.

Let's have Mojang be scientifically accurate for this small instance and change that 'a' to an 'e' to help further educate people about the wonderous world of archaeology.

I completely agree. Rabbits (in-game) are also found in flower forests, giving the biome some needed life. The cherry grove too has an abundance of flowers (on the ground and from within the trees), so it simply makes logical sense that rabbits would spawn there. Secondly, as of right now, the cherry grove biome is lacking some life in it. The fast moving, timid, and jumpy rabbits of Minecraft could really help fill in the void that is present in the cherry grove as of April 23, 2023.

The added addition of foxes would also be a great addition. Seeing as foxes in Minecraft hunt rabbits, it would give the biome even more life than just having rabbits. It also adds some story to the biome; seeing how if the player were to travel through the biome, they could very well come across the drops of a rabbit on the ground. Adding foxes to the cherry grove would also give even more reason to stay in the biome because as of April 23, 2023, the fox only spawns in certain "spruce tree biomes." Giving a new place for the fox to spawn could certainly give reason for a player to stay.

I for one really do hope that these changes get added to Minecraft because of the logical reasonings, potential story implications, and the added diversity behind such changes. After all, the Trails And Tales update is all about more diversity and story, giving even further reason for these changes. Mojang, I hope you take these reasons into consideration.

Sincerely, 

Moldy Ham

Honestly? I absolutely agree. And by technicality, this could apply to frogs as well. Maybe even make them slightly smaller than normal frogs due to the cooler environment. And if we want to go all out, give cherry grove frogs the colors of fire-bellied toads to give some extra spice to the biome.
They could also stack similar to slabs!

In Bedrock Edition, you can already dye armor using a cauldron, and it has the added bonus of being able to mix colors instead of only using one premade dye color. I'm sure it'll be added to Java edition eventually.
